text: {"grade": 1, "reasoning": "The response explicitly addresses the jurisdictional asymmetry inherent in traditional BITs, stating: \"Investor-state arbitration was designed as a one-directional mechanism: the investor activates it; the state defends. Nothing in that architecture naturally accommodates a state bringing its own affirmative claim for relief.\" This directly satisfies the criterion requiring mention of jurisdictional asymmetry (traditional BITs grant rights to investors but not obligations to states).", "criterion_id": "7a4768bf-62c5-4ccc-b79c-ca96f0d8f557"}
